thread.title: South Florida hotels are fuller, charging more compared to last year
thread.title_full: South Florida hotels are fuller, charging more compared to last year

author: Emon Reiser
title: South Florida hotels are fuller, charging more compared to last year
text:
Skyline view of downtown Miami, Florida. After a slow mid-summer , business began picking up for South Florida's hotels in July. Recent data from STR, Inc. showed that a higher percentage of travelers who stayed the night in the tri-county area's hotels compared to last year, and they paid higher rates for their rooms. Miami-Dade County Miami-Dade's hotel occupancy rate in July rose to 78.3 percent, up from 75 percent compared to the same time last year. In June, the occupancy rate was 71.7 percent. Last month, the county's average daily rate rose to $155.69 up from $148.45 in July 2014. In June, the average daily rate was $148.50. Revenue per available room rose to $121.25 in July, up from $111.30 year-over-year. In June, the revenue per available room was $106.47. Miami-Dade County has about 50,000 hotel rooms, more than Broward County and Palm Beach County combined. Broward County Broward County's hotel occupancy rate in July rose to 78.3 percent, up from 75.6 percent the same time last year. In June, the occupancy rate was 73.8 percent. Last month, the county's average daily rate rose to $108.78 up from $103.69 in July 2014. In June, the average daily rate was $108.05. Revenue per available room rose to $85.18 in July, up from $78.38 year-over-year. In June, the revenue per available room was $79.77. Broward County has about 30,000 hotel rooms. Palm Beach County Palm Beach County's hotel occupancy rate in July rose to 68.6 percent, up slightly from 68.3 percent the same time last year. In June, the occupancy rate was 67.2 percent. Last month, the county's average daily rate rose to $121.81 up from $112.30 in July 2014. In June, the average daily rate was $121.49. Revenue per available room fell to $83.52 in July, down from $76.73 year-over-year. In June, the revenue per available room was $81.61. Across the country, the hotel industry's average occupancy was up 2.3 percent to 75.3 percent and its average daily rate also rose 5.9 percent to $124.32. Palm Beach County has about 16,000 hotel rooms. "The July occupancy of 75.3 percent was the highest single occupancy of any month ever recorded by STR," said Jan Freitag, STRâ€™s senior VP for lodging insights in a statement. In July, every major tourism market in the U.S. reported year-over-year growth in average daily rates and revenue per available room. But the Orlando area stood out. The Central Florida region saw the largest rise in occupancy across the top markets in the U.S., up 8.4 percent to 84 percent year-over-year. It also reported double-digit growth in its revenue-per-available-room rate, up 19.4 percent to $93.24 compared to the same time last year. Comparably, South Florida welcomed about 35 million visitors in 2014 and Central Florida drew more than 62 million visitors. Central Florida was the most-visited destination in the U.S last year.
